nonEditableReason.message: The Parent Link is only available to Jira Premium users.

requestType.name: Order Custom 3D Silicone Bolus
requestType.description: Please complete this form once for each bolus required.

comments.body:
[~accountid:5f3ca74d333edb0043b0b593] [~accountid:5f56efe840e048006efee318] 

I’ve just had a crack at the leg and there are a few issues/questions I wanted to raise

Did the filler tube work with the slot connection - it looks really small when against a large object like the leg

!image-20210614-010929.png|width=389,height=912!

This mould is very wide - here is the max print height shown

!image-20210614-011752.png|width=492,height=717!

So it would either need to be printed in that orientation or split in both directions - that would be 4 parts for each side plus 2 or 3 for the core - total of 10 to 11 printed parts

!image-20210614-011937.png|width=682,height=1049!

Finally some areas like the tip of the toe has overhangs in most print orientations

Here is what I’ve got so far - testing out the 5 sided plugs (the seam gets a bit more complicated with the core) - any feedback on things that should be changed etc. would be great

!image-20210614-012136.png|width=1215,height=953!

[~accountid:60b04dd8aadf840071f6e205]  Interesting.. I think the best test would be to split the part to make sure they fit. Sooner or later we’re going to have this issue of parts being too large.. I have scoped the printer capacity to cope with ~2 of these in a day. I’ll have 25 B1’s when the next consignment arrives.



We haven't tested the new mold yet. We’re testing various sealing methods. The hot melt glue is too good. Sealing up the outside seam with a soldering iron, worked, but was slow and tedious. The latest is a sausage of modelling clay pressed into the trench you’ve modeled. It holds water, so this looks like a good solution. We can re use the clay too.

For the toes on the core, perhaps chop the toes off with a vertical slice and we can super glue them onto the core again. If you can add a register on the toes that would be great. Like an s shaped worm as used on the seam, would be adequate. Just enough so that we can quickly press the toes on and let the glue set.

!IMG_20210615_133133938_HDR.jpg|width=1800,height=4000!

If you can slice the mould to fit, we can print it off. This is a good test of our systems.

Also the small filler connection between the filler tube and the model is fine, even though it looks small. Remember there will be a lot of vertical pressure “head” from the filler tube pushing down from above, so I doubt we’ll have any flow issues. Having said that, the leg does have a lot of volume to fill, so perhaps add a second branch to help it flow in.. I was discussing this filler with Alex. I think if we can model a conical filler tube that narrows towards the lower section that will save us a lot of material over time. We’re going to try a kitchen funnel sealed onto the top of the filler tube with the modeling clay to help fill the mould as quickly as possible. Can you estimate the volume of this bolus?

!image-20210615-034606.png|width=647,height=469!

[~accountid:5f3ca74d333edb0043b0b593] 

* Slicing of the toes is a much better idea (I was stuck in thinking of making the print volume similar) - if it wasn’t for the filler tube area A could be completely removed (maybe a hose would work instead)

!image-20210615-035431.png|width=797,height=1272!



* Clay seems like a great idea if it works well - it should also be much easier to remove than the hot glue and it’s great if it’s reusable



* BTW talking of a larger volume printer - how is the BLV going?



* Just saw your second comment - I’ll add the second branch and check the volume soon
The blv is gathering dust. Its too much of a “project” rather than a ready to run reliable printer. it needs a new bed and about a weeks worth of tuning.
[~accountid:60b04dd8aadf840071f6e205] any developments with these mould parts? That “A” section can get chopped and I’ll print a filler pipe.

[~accountid:5f3ca74d333edb0043b0b593] 

I’ve been thinking about how to make parts like this without undercuts by slicing off the top and bottom but I need to think though the ramifications a bit better first.

I’ll finish this off after lunch and upload it

[~accountid:5f3ca74d333edb0043b0b593] 

I’ve uploaded the files

All of the additional adjustments make the CAD process take longer than I had previously thought - it’s not too bad but I thought I’d mention it.

!image-20210616-040834.png|width=1195,height=1026!

I estimate about 1734ml for the cast (including the filler tube to the top of the leg)

[~accountid:5f3ca74d333edb0043b0b593] [~accountid:5f56efe840e048006efee318] 

The locator at the joint for the core does mean you’ll need to print the top half with support

[~accountid:60b04dd8aadf840071f6e205] These parts are too large. The upper leg will take 3 days to print. I’ll slice them into chunks in prusa slicer. Just keep that 3.6l print volume in mind. This’ll take the entire print farm to print.. but its a good test\!

[~accountid:5f3ca74d333edb0043b0b593] [~accountid:5f56efe840e048006efee318] 

Oh yeah, sorry about that - completely forgot about the print volume.

The upper leg core when I check shows it as 2.2l - when I run this though Cura without tweaking the settings much it comes out at about 19 hours (still to long and it would take longer than that but faster that 3 days - I might be doing something wrong but are you talking about a different part when you say ‘upper leg’ or what printer settings are you using?

BTW I found out you can check the volume inside 3Dcoat so this should make things a lot easier

!image-20210616-055044.png|width=1136,height=897!

I could trim down the blocks looking form the z projection - this would speed up print times and reduce material use but I’m not sure how much it might affect ease of clamping

!image-20210616-054522.png|width=601,height=883!

Triming the edges can make quite a difference - one part went from 2.6l to 1.5l

I’ve already kicked off some prints so I’ll just continue from here. Nice to know we can see the volume in there. If you cast your eye up and to your right, you’ll see a drop down menu showing “In preproduction” this menu sets the current order status. Once you’ve uploaded all parts you can change this to “Mould Production” and I can create an automation to move the job from your queue (thats coming) to a 'pre production queue, which would be Alex and I.

.. then it’ll alert us to a new job.

The flow and steps look like this…

New Order

In pre production

Mould Production

Mould Assembly

Bolus Production

Inspection

Shipped

We can move from some steps to the next, and from others to many, for example Inspection can move to Shipped or back to any step prior for rework.

[~accountid:5f3ca74d333edb0043b0b593] [~accountid:5f56efe840e048006efee318] 

The dropdown menu is great - that should be really useful

I’ve had a quick look at the plaster type mould - from a CAD side it looks quite doable but some solutions would need to be made for support and alignment

Here are some notes

!image-20210617-014718.png|width=927,height=951!

I’ve uploaded a very rough approximation of a shell part to dropbox (AB-84 - shell time test) if someone could run that through the slicer to get a ballpark idea of the time vs the previous mould section then the would give a rough idea of how much of a difference it would make (this is at a 10mm wall - making it thinner might also work)

[~accountid:5f3ca74d333edb0043b0b593] [~accountid:5f56efe840e048006efee318] 

I had another crack at the shell type mould but I haven’t tried the flanges yet

Maybe splitting the top and bottom would make it easier to print

!image-20210618-021508.png|width=1177,height=1003!

This is what a section looks like

!image-20210618-021653.png|width=931,height=779!

 I’ll wait till I hear something regarding the print time of the shell style part (that I uploaded yesterday) vs a normal mould part before trying one of these with flanges

This looks great\! Im still printing the version 1 of this mould. It seems I missed one part. Which means the first version will be ready Monday. I’ll slice up these parts too posted today, and print them over the weekend so we can compare next week. perhaps if you’re free Monday you can come past and help pour in the silicone?

There are two items of feedback so far with Ver1 of this mould;

* The pentagon at the top needs relief for the core mould to slide in. perhaps we can use a slot shape, A rectangle with radiused corners instead? I’ll snip these off with some side cutters. 
* !image-20210618-040419.png|width=1083,height=755!

* The ceiling of this mould is horizontal. So there is a risk of trapped bubbles, as the mould fills. Ideally the mould should always have a tilt up to the fill vents. We could prop the mould up at an angle, but might be easier to introduce within the mould itself? At least only one vent, as for this mould, one of the two vents you’ve added will need to get plugged.

Also Version 3. You submitted today looks really great. I see a few potential issues though;

On the left hand seam the square edge.. the B1’s are not giving crisp outer right angles. The axes are either not slowing down before a turn or the extruder is over extruding, so best to chamfer this edge on the lower half of the leg in the view - shown with a blue line.

On the right hand side if this part gets over clamped the lower half of the leg mould will slide into the cavity up to the ridges. Better to reverse the taper into a captive pocket so shown with red and blue lines on the right.

I’ll quickly slice this and see what the print times are.

!image-20210618-041000.png|width=1236,height=1045!

[~accountid:5f3ca74d333edb0043b0b593] 

Good points - thanks for that

Just to be clear I didn’t upload an entire mould just that single part (the one where we had trouble getting to show up on dropbox) to get a time estimate

* I noticed the pentagon issue today - the work around I have is to add the pentagon after making the split and then aligning the corners with the split line
* So just a single vent right - regarding the angle, tilting the object in 3D coat would work but increase print time, I think putting a block under the mould to angle it (as you suggested) might better solution (at least for now - having things horizontal in 3Dcoat makes a few steps of the process easier too
* I was a bit concerned about the square angles too - I think I have a way to chamfer the edge and add the edge bead using the same path - that would make it almost no extra work, it looks a bit like this
!image-20210618-052639.png|width=838,height=825!
I’ve uploaded these two parts to dropbox (in the shell test folder) - so you can test print to see if they fit together OK
!image-20210618-053041.png|width=865,height=760!

Changing the internal to stop the part sliding in is a more involved process - I’ll need to think of a reasonable way to try that

That leg looks much quicker. 15 hrs for the 1/2 leg. The ones I already printed were ~15 hours for a 1/4 leg

!image-20210618-064636.png|width=1840,height=1042!

Oh right, that sounds promising

I had a go at adding a flange - this is a few extra steps but a groove could also be added here for alignment, although I have some other ideas too. I didn’t do the core as I though I’d get some feedback from the prints etc. first as well as having a think about how best to do the top and bottom surface etc. 

!image-20210618-081056.png|width=419,height=919!

!image-20210618-081109.png|width=652,height=810!

The sample worked out really well\! The parts register together very nicely.

!IMG_20210621_111541.jpg|width=1800,height=4000!

!IMG_20210621_111605.jpg|width=4000,height=1800!

The prints look nice - do you think there is enough of a ridge that you can smear some of the clay in to create a seal then use rubber bands or straps to hold the halves together?

I’ve been thinking about a top and bottom cap for these - I’ll have a chat with you to hash it out a bit when I come by
Yes the ridge is just right.

I’ve uploaded the modified mould parts to drop box in a new folder (Top parts to reprint) - I’ve cut away some of the top and added a wall to help contain the silicone - If you don’t want the wall so high or at all you can remove it in the slicer
Great\! They’re printing now. We should be able to try them from tomorrow

I’ve been having a look at how make the top cap etc. and came up with this

!image-20210623-040034.png|width=664,height=810!

!image-20210623-040104.png|width=515,height=635!

Still needs some work but it should make filling the mould easier



Also I had an idea for holding the moulds together if the bulldog clips don’t work - a slot that you could slide a wingnut and bolt into then chinch it up - that way you would never need to take off the nut

Obviously the clips would be faster (both to model and to use) if they work though

!image-20210623-032714.png|width=358,height=398!

!image-20210623-032735.png|width=597,height=485!

I’ve tried using ‘liquid electrical tape’ (I only used this because I had it on hand - it’s similar to the frisket but thicker) and have some thoughts about this

I think the idea of a soft interface material is the way to go

I looks like it worked OK but the application is probably a bit finicky (but that’s partly due to using an old bottle)

!image-20210624-034749.png|width=326,height=441!

Once dry it stays soft and can be peeled off

!image-20210624-035059.png|width=590,height=413!

I think a thin bead of something like this works better (see left hand side) but using a syringe or something like that would be a better way to apply it)

!image-20210624-035203.png|width=920,height=509!

----

I also had a look at the silicone tube option - If I find a local supplier I can order some and print a test - I think this might be the best option

!image-20210624-031948.png|width=613,height=519!

!image-20210624-032002.png|width=323,height=264!

I had a quick look and found this

[Silicone Tubing, 1 ID x 3 OD mm (10 Meter Roll) - Buy Online at LabDirect|https://www.labdirect.com.au/silicone-tubing-1-id-x-3-od-mm-10-meter-roll/]

These might be even better (they have sore hardness ratings but I don’t have a good feel for what they mean - you would have a better idea but I figure the softer the better)

[Closed Cell Silicone Foam Strip , Food Grade Silicone Foam Insulation Strips (silicone-tubings.com)|http://www.silicone-tubings.com/sale-10042342-closed-cell-silicone-foam-strip-food-grade-silicone-foam-insulation-strips.html]

[Soft Colored Silicone Foam Strip No Poison For High Temperature Sealing (silicone-tubings.com)|http://www.silicone-tubings.com/sale-10042348-soft-colored-silicone-foam-strip-no-poison-for-high-temperature-sealing.html]

Another option would be an adhesive backed gasket tape

[Gasket Tape, Adhesive-Backed Foam Gasket Tape | Stockwell Elastomerics|https://www.stockwell.com/gasket-tape/]



This stuff doesn’t seem expensive and could be reusable:

The silicone or foam tubing/strips would be reusable and hold in place if the mould is designed correctly

!image-20210624-034401.png|width=490,height=337!

!image-20210624-034414.png|width=555,height=440!

The adhesive would hold in place with more design options but probably wouldn’t be reusable
